user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetErrorName:
```c
int32 OS_GetErrorName(int32 error_num, os_err_name_t *err_name)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    const OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t *Error;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(err_name);

    Error = OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE;
    while (Error->Name != NULL && Error->Number != error_num)
    {
        ++Error;
    }

    if (Error->Number != error_num)
    {
        Error = OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE;
        while (Error->Name != NULL && Error->Number != error_num)
        {
            ++Error;
        }
    }

    if (Error->Number == error_num && Error->Name != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(*err_name, Error->Name, sizeof(*err_name) - 1);
        *err_name[sizeof(*err_name) - 1] = 0;
        return_code                      = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        snprintf(*err_name, OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH, "OS_UNKNOWN(%d)", (int)error_num);
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    (*err_name)[OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH - 1] = '\0';

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetErrorName:

{

#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...

typedef char os_err_name_t[OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH]

Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 14.3 applies to controlling expressions of selection and iteration statements. The two while loops above are iteration statements whose controlling expressions should be verified for invariance (they are the only loop controlling expressions in the function). Other constructs in the function do not need investigation for this rule: the if conditions depend on variables that can vary at runtime (Error and error_num), the parameter check macro is a pointer validation (the macro expansion is not shown as an invariant controlling expression here), and the remaining statements are assignments/strncpy/snprintf/returns which are not iteration/selection controlling expressions. Therefore only the two while loops merit investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
